data.title: magic _str method
data.body:
Python has many magic methods, one of them [**str**](https://docs.python.org/2/reference/datamodel.html#object.__str__) 

I propose to add same magic to GDScript. This PR is just proof of concept. I tested some expressions and all works ok, but probably I forgot something

Example:

```
func _str(): return "Test.gd script"
```

Was:

```
print(self) # [Node:588]
print("Init %s" % self) # Init [Node:552]
```

Now:

```
print(self) # Test.gd script
print("Init %s" % self) # init Test.gd script
```

data.title: EditorPlugin can't use scripts/scenes in subfolders
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1 master 3b676439789e5816a66e935f4d98accacc698943

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
A plugin can't use GDScripts and Scenes placed in subfolders. Currently it seems required to have them placed in the root plugin folder.
In the example downloadable below, the button's caption should change on click.
Console displays error:  scene/resources/scene_format_text.cpp:122 - Couldn't load external resource: res://Scripts/button.gd

**Steps to reproduce:**
Download the example plugin below.
Unzip it in a new Godot project (you should have an "addon/" folder).
Enable the plugin.
The dock appears on the left, but clicking it has no effect.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
https://cloud.murgia.fr/index.php/s/fvPx2aQwtbaEilp

data.title: (Array) .pop_front, .pop_back & .remove return values instead of void
data.body:
`.pop_front`, `.pop_back` & `.remove` now return values instead of `void`. Things
that don't work or I didn't know how to properly handle:
1. `.pop_front` & `.pop_back` shows in the help menu `Object` as return value.
   I know this is incorrect but if not `Object` than what? Cause it
   can't be `void`. It needs to be a generic type that includes all the
   `Array` types
2. `.remove` works OK as long as it has something to return, if the index
   is out of bounds it just terminates the application and gives this
   error:
   
   ```
   ERROR: operator[]: Condition ' p_index<0 || p_index>=size() ' is true. returned: aux
   At: core/vector.h:144
   ```
   
   That's because I used `ERR_FAIL_INDEX_V` inside of `DVector::remove()`,
   but I don't know how else to implement this.

data.title: Under MacOS Sierra beta, Godot engine 2.1 UI is quite broken (for me)
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
macOS 10.12 Beta Build 16A304a
Godot 2.1 release (v2.1.stable.official)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Opening a project produces an unusable UI.  It appears many UI elements are missing and the overall UI is super zoomed. 

**Steps to reproduce:**
-- Download the example code onto a machine with the above beta
-- Import the example code folder via the Godot UI 
-- Double-Click on an item in the project list (Glass bubbles for example)
-- Godot relaunches with a full screen window UI that is broken (image attached)
-- two finger mouse scrolling in the screen can make some of the background image (from venice) show a bit more ,but nothing works as expected and there are no controls, etc.

-- also the "quit" functions for Godot do not work.  The Godot menu doesn't work (on the mac menu bar) and the right click menu in the dock has a "quit" option equivilent to hitting command-q but that does not work.  Have to force quit.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

**Additional Notes:**

I have not attempted to build 2.2 from scratch.  I am running macOS betas as they are released.  Sierra is expected to be released within a month from now.  I can run test builds and help debug, and can build from scratch if need be, just let me know. 
![godot-initial](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1340910/18027017/884e4518-6c1d-11e6-9008-aa687f871e35.jpeg)

data.title: Visual Scripting - Game crash after close
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10, Godot https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/d015d93b8f94f55b26f874781ac7fd0a53e68227

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Always after close game with running  scene with code create with Visual Scripting, game crash. After debugging in Visual Studio:
`Exception thrown: write access violation.
ringptr->prev was 0x1.
If there is a handler for this exception, the program may be safely continued.`

line 299 
`ringptr->prev->next = ringptr->next;`
in function `void MemoryPoolStaticMalloc::_free(void *p_ptr)` in file "memory_pool_static_malloc.cpp".

data.title: Visual Scripting - Node "Comment" block possibility to select other nodes
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10, Godot https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/d015d93b8f94f55b26f874781ac7fd0a53e68227

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Afer drop "Comment" node in Visual Scripting mode it is not possible to select the block on node. Comment mode is always selected.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Drop function node and example call node.
2. Drop comment mode.
3. Try to select nodes from point 1 (with rectangle selection).

data.title: CanvasModulate node doesn't affect Sprite2D with "add" blend mode.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu Linux 16.04 64b, godot version d015d93

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I just found that CanvasModulate now affects only child nodes unlike before, which is incredibly convenient, but it doesn't seem to alter Sprite2D whose blend mode is set to Add.
![snapshot12](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323651/18026440/9f79ca4a-6c46-11e6-96a1-579b722881ca.png)
While I can see many reasons to keep alpha-blended effects from inheriting the modulation (to darken the background but keep the lights shiny), this is slightly inconvenient as seen in the example screenshot, which is trying to fade the entire background. Perhaps some toggle could be added to allow both things?

**Steps to reproduce:**
Add a Sprite2D with blend mode set to "Add" somewhere as a children of CanvasModulate, then change color of CanvasModulate.

data.title: Condition 'det==0' is true
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 - v2.1.stable.official on Steam

**Issue description**:
Debug errors with set_transform and scaling to Vector2(0,0). This is most likely a very minor issue, but it won't hurt to still report this issue. I'd also like to include that I crashed once already after debugging the project.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a 2D Sprite node and add a Button child node. 
In the _ready() function:
`set_transform(Matrix32(get_transform().scaled(Vector2(0,0))))`

data.title: GDScript Variable Inheritance
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** 2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I am horrible at explaining things so I made this picture. I think re-referencing the variable is kind of "bland", (I mean, it works), but when I have 10 or so plus variables things kind of get out of hand. And I wish I could just inherit the variables from a node and use them without using the `.variable` notation to reference. For example:
![1234](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10387670/18022222/eb345266-6ba1-11e6-8903-1cad3d99642e.png)

We can use a keyword `inherit` and then give it a parameter to the node we want to inherit the variables from.  This would ofcourse be an optional feature, but yeah

data.title: Adds enums to GDScript
data.body:
Fixes #2966

Quick sample usage:

``` gdscript
enum {TLIE_FLOOR, TLIE_BRICK, TLIE_SPIKE, TLIE_MAX}
# TILE_FLOOR == 1, TILE_MAX == 4
enum {A = TLIE_BRICK,B,C}
# A==2, B==3, C==4
enum {PI_FLOORED = floor(PI), PI_CEILED = ceil(PI), PI_ROUNDED = round(PI)}
# Allows only ints though..
enum {TEST_A, TEST_B, TEST_C, # Also should allow newlines..
  TEST_A1 = TEST_A * 10, TEST_B1 = TEST_B * 10, TEST_C1 = TEST_C * 10}
# Because, why not (unintended consequence of the parsing code, heh)?
```

**DO NOT MERGE** I have to implement @djrm's proposal first.

data.title: fix string iterator
data.body:
Since strings are null-terminated, size() returns incorrect length,
so use length() instead.

fixes #6287

data.title: What's up with the for loop and strings?
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 - v2.1.stable.official on Steam

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Some empty character is showing up when I use the "for x in string:" loop.

**Steps to reproduce:**

```
    var myString = "foo"
    for i in myString:
        print(i)
```

**Output:**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8620268/17990560/f94dc5e6-6b04-11e6-9577-ff3f29070a17.png)

Nothing strange yet. Even if you were to loop this, you'd still get "foofoofoo". Why? Because empty strings won't get printed. 

But what if we do this?

```
    for i in myString:
        var printMe = "*" + i + "*"
        print(printMe)
```

**Output:**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8620268/17990647/8f5f572a-6b05-11e6-836f-166b4bc9cb4e.png)

This is when things start to get strange.

We can try this too:

```
    for i in myString:
        print(i.length())
```

**Output:**
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8620268/17990837/60b76f3c-6b07-11e6-8817-0f4c43b38d8e.png)

What's causing this? Of course you can just do "for i in range(0,myString.length())" instead, but it doesn't change the fact that there is still a problem with "for i in myString".

data.title: Animating CollisionShape extents makes KinematicBody2D invisible to Area2D
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 64bit
Godot v2.1 32bit

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The setup:
The scene contains a small KinematicBody2D and a bigger Area2D. The KinematicBody2D can be moved with the arrow keys and prints "ENTER" and "EXIT" to the console when it enters or exits the Area2D, respectively. The KinematicBody2D also contains an AnimationPlayer, with a 3 seconds long animation consisting of nothing but a single key at the beginning of a track that animates the extents of the KinematicBody2D's collision shape, it doesn't actually change the extents, just sets them to the same numbers that they already had. This animation does not play automatically or loop, you can make it play once by pressing the Z key.

How it behaves:
If you move inside the area, it will print "ENTER" normally, then if you press Z while inside it will print "EXIT", then 3 seconds later print "ENTER". If you are outside and press Z before entering, it will only print "ENTER" after the 3 seconds are over. The KinematicBody2D is effectively invisible to the Area2D while the animation is playing.

**Steps to reproduce:**
See sample project.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[AnimatingCollisionShape.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/438225/AnimatingCollisionShape.zip)

I apologize in advance if I messed up and this is not a bug.

data.title: Connecting signal to inherited function shouldn't create a new one
data.body:
**Godot version:** 9c6175db11ff72603ae58789a462b33ec1e910f8

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When signal is connected through editor (i.e. not code) to inherited function (e.g. Node-based: queue_free, emit_signal, etc), a new function with that name is created. Better behavior would be to detect that function exist and automatically deselect "Create Function" option and indicate that the function is already defined on parent class.

data.title: [Feature Request] Auto Spritesheet Slicing
data.body: @godotengine  should have auto spritesheet slicing, which will greatly enhance productivity for 2D game development. For example unity has a very good .png sprite sheet slicer, it automatically(most of the time accurately) slices the entire sheet into individual sprites which also enhances game performance as only one texture has to be loaded on the memory and each sprite will have its own bounds.

data.title: Open file by clicking on its name/path in editor
data.body:
Would be nice to be able to open file by clicking (or ctrl+click, or at least as right-click option, or hotkey) on its name in script editor.

Related: #2982

data.title: AssetLib handling of asset upgrades
data.body:
*Bugsquad edit.*

**Godot version:**
2.1.3, current master

When upgrade assets / reinstalling a new version, the editor will by default deselect all files with the same filename as in the previously installed version. This is non-optimal in the case of a plugin that users typically wouldn't edit, and for which they'd which the new files to overwrite the old ones (and actually the orphaned old files to be removed).

Long story short, we need better handling of asset versions, with the ability for the project and the assetlib to keep track of installed versions, and to replace them by newer version. Files with user-side modifications that would be overwritten during an upgrade should be backed up.

------------

That makes no sense when asset is from category tools (possible also other category).
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10463138/17902246/d5d65ce4-6966-11e6-8e61-1873e2b02500.png)

I added it first on this repro https://github.com/godotengine/asset-library/issues/52
